content: Are seasons caused by the Earth being closer to the Sun during the summer and farther away during the winter?

Actually, that's a common misconception. The Earth's distance from the Sun isn't what causes seasons. Seasons are primarily caused by the tilt of the Earth's axis as it orbits the Sun. The Earth's axis is tilted at an angle of approximately 23.5 degrees relative to its orbit. This means that different parts of the Earth receive varying amounts of sunlight throughout the year, leading to the seasons we experience.

During summer in the Northern Hemisphere, for example, the North Pole is tilted towards the Sun, so the Sun's rays hit that part of the Earth more directly, causing warmer temperatures and longer days. At the same time, the Southern Hemisphere is tilted away from the Sun, experiencing winter with shorter days and less direct sunlight.

Meanwhile, the Earth's orbit is slightly elliptical, so there are times when it is closer to the Sun (perihelion) and times when it is farther away (aphelion). However, this variation in distance has a much smaller effect on seasons than the tilt of the Earth's axis. In fact, the Earth is actually closest to the Sun in early January, which is winter in the Northern Hemisphere, further illustrating that distance isn't the primary factor causing seasons.

So, to summarize, seasons are mainly due to the tilt of the Earth's axis and the resulting variation in sunlight received at different latitudes throughout the year, not because of the Earth's varying distance from the Sun.
